title: Fatal: Failed to register the Ethereum service: failed to retrieve genesis from ancient EOF
body:
#### System information
OS: `Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS (Hyper-V VM)`
RAM: `65536 MB`
CPU: `12 vCPU ([2] Intel Xeon E5-2670)`
OS Drive: `Samsung 960 Pro (Shared 62GB)`
Chaindata Drive: `Samsung 970Pro (1TB)`
Ancient Chaindata Drive: `Synology NAS 8TB`

Geth version: `Geth
Version: 1.10.15-stable
Architecture: amd64
Go Version: go1.16.4
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=/usr/local/go
`
OS & Version: `Linux`

Geth Parameters: `/eth1/bin/geth --datadir /eth1/data --datadir.ancient /mnt/nas/data --port 30303 --mainnet --syncmode snap --txlookuplimit=0 --cache.preimages --cache=32768`

#### Background

- The server is connected to UPS, however due to length of power outage wasn't able to sustain power and was abruptly turned off on May 7th
- Same applied to Synology storage hosting ancient chaindata
- When the server restarted geth autostarted and failed to operate (presumably because of data corruption?)
- Right before it failed it was "Truncating dangling head", what does that mean?


#### Expected behaviour

- Geth is able to restart or repair after unexpected power outage?
- I've had other unexpected reboots that it was able to survive in the past

#### Actual behaviour

- Geth is unable to repair\operate


#### Snippet of Geth Log
```
-- Logs begin at Tue 2021-10-12 20:17:24 UTC, end at Wed 2022-05-25 15:15:40 UTC. --
```

If I understand your setup correctly, you have 2 machines, one compute and one storage server. The compute holding the main database on an SSD and the storage server holding the ancients on an HDD. Also you're saying that after a simultaneous downtime and restart, Geth had issues with the ancient folder.

Could it happen that your compute server came back online faster that the storage one and when Geth was started the ancient mount point hasn't yet been made? In that case I could see Geth reading an empty ancient folder and having issues that it's out of sync with the ssd database.

> If I understand your setup correctly, you have 2 machines, one compute and one storage server. The compute holding the main database on an SSD and the storage server holding the ancients on an HDD. Also you're saying that after a simultaneous downtime and restart, Geth had issues with the ancient folder.

That's correct, the ancient data mount is part of a LUN attached to the compute VM via Hyper-V server and presented as a virtual local disk inside the VM

> Could it happen that your compute server came back online faster that the storage one and when Geth was started the ancient mount point hasn't yet been made? In that case I could see Geth reading an empty ancient folder and having issues that it's out of sync with the ssd database.

It should not. Hyper-v won't start the VM if it detects one of the drives is missing (i.e waiting for iSCSI LUN to re-attach from NAS) . I tested this again today to validate. Therefore, when the VM can back online the LUN containing ancient data would of had to been available and re-attached before geth started.

I suspect maybe some the ancient files got corrupted from an unclean shutdown due to powerloss? 
Anyway to vet this? Seems most of the data is there (ancient folder size is 314G)

So I started trying to debug the chaindata and ancient to figure out what's happening. Here is my working theory:

1. Geth node suffered a power outage May 07 15:57:31 UTC (and the chaindata is considered an unclean shutdown?)
2. Power was restored around May 07 ~16:20:00 and NAS was available as Geth node restarted automatically @ 16:22:35 UTC
3. (Geth detected unclean shutdown?) and began `Truncating dangling head` @ 16:22:55 UTC
3a. I'm assuming it did this because it's trying to align chaindata with ancient from unclean shutdown?
4. The file `hashes.0000.rdat` end-state is 0 bytes and it's modified date is during the `Truncating dangling head` events @ May  7 16:22 UTC

During debugging, I also noticed the hashes table from ancient has an item property count of `14640694` but the file is 0 bytes.


The code I believe is suspect in this event is from `freezer_table.go`
```
// Keep truncating both files until they come in sync
	contentExp = int64(lastIndex.offset)
	for contentExp != contentSize {
		// Truncate the head file to the last offset pointer
		if contentExp < contentSize {
			t.logger.Warn("Truncating dangling head", "indexed", common.StorageSize(contentExp), "stored", common.StorageSize(contentSize))
			if err := truncateFreezerFile(t.head, contentExp); err != nil {
				return err
			}
			contentSize = contentExp
		}
```
According to geth log: `table=hashes  indexed=0.00B stored=446.80MiB`
So if indexed = 0B then stored would get truncated to 0B? Which might make sense why the hashes.0000.rdat is empty and the genesis hash cannot be found?

My question is why did repair() cause this?
